revisions:
[{'created': '2015-12-02 12:11:42.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/tests/unit/test_emc_xtremio.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/emc/xtremio.py'], 'message': "Take into consideration races in XtremIOClient3

When working with FC and xtremio is using XtremIOClient3 on FC's
terminate_connection we can get VolumeBackendAPIException saying a
resource could not be found when we shouldn't.

The cause is that Client3 is open to race conditions on 2 methods,
find_lunmap and num_of_mapped_volumes, where a list of mappings is first
retrieved and then we iterate this list to retrieved additional info on
the mappings.

The race would happen if one of the mappings is removed from the backend
in the time it takes to retrieve the additional info after we have
retrieved the list.

This patch fixes this issue by ignoring any mappings that have been
removed and are now NotFound when retrieving additional information for
a mapping in those 2 methods.

This patch also fixes this kind of race problems on volume creation
since it uses find_lumap method.

Closes-Bug: #1521143
Change-Id: I40831e04093ff475395870a333211dd0cb60440f
(cherry picked from commit 89480f159231eae154119da6b46432849b9df20a)
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Take into consideration races in XtremIOClient3

When working with FC and xtremio is using XtremIOClient3 on FC's
terminate_connection we can get VolumeBackendAPIException saying a
resource could not be found when we shouldn't.

The cause is that Client3 is open to race conditions on 2 methods,
find_lunmap and num_of_mapped_volumes, where a list of mappings is first
retrieved and then we iterate this list to retrieved additional info on
the mappings.

The race would happen if one of the mappings is removed from the backend
in the time it takes to retrieve the additional info after we have
retrieved the list.

This patch fixes this issue by ignoring any mappings that have been
removed and are now NotFound when retrieving additional information for
a mapping in those 2 methods.

This patch also fixes this kind of race problems on volume creation
since it uses find_lumap method.

Closes-Bug: #1521143
Change-Id: I40831e04093ff475395870a333211dd0cb60440f
(cherry picked from commit 89480f159231eae154119da6b46432849b9df20a)

commit_message:
Remove unfixable FIXME

There is a note in test_catalog.py saying that we should fix the
endpoint create status code from 200 OK to 201 Created.

This isn't allowed according to the API working group guidelines:
http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/evaluating_api_changes.html#evaluating-api-changes

Change-Id: Id52c61f119d4e9b1168ddc2d1ebc760fca1d640d

commit_message:
Use new_policy_ref consistently

Do not manually create policy refs. Use new_policy_ref instead.

Change-Id: I7b6ec22430fcffae69cab1b276e41390314be5cc

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-11-04 11:10:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Put part-replicas where they go

It's harder than it sounds.  There was really three challenges.

Challenge #1 Initial Assignment
===============================

Before starting to assign parts on this new shiny ring you've
constructed, maybe we'll pause for a moment up front and consider the
lay of the land.  This process is called the replica_plan.

The replica_plan approach is separating part assignment failures into
two modes:

 1) we considered the cluster topology and it's weights and came up with
    the wrong plan

 2) we failed to execute on the plan

I failed at both parts plenty of times before I got it this close.  I'm
sure a counter example still exists, but when we find it the new helper
methods will let us reason about where things went wrong.

Challenge #2 Fixing Placement
=============================

With a sound plan in hand, it's much easier to fail to execute on it the
less material you have to execute with - so we gather up as many parts
as we can - as long as we think we can find them a better home.

Picking the right parts for gather is a black art - when you notice a
balance is slow it's because it's spending so much time iterating over
replica2part2dev trying to decide just the right parts to gather.

The replica plan can help at least in the gross dispersion collection to
gather up the worst offenders first before considering balance.  I think
trying to avoid picking up parts that are stuck to the tier before
falling into a forced grab on anything over parts_wanted helps with
stability generally - but depending on where the parts_wanted are in
relation to the full devices it's pretty easy pick up something that'll
end up really close to where it started.

I tried to break the gather methods into smaller pieces so it looked
like I knew what I was doing.

Going with a MAXIMUM gather iteration instead of balance (which doesn't
reflect the replica_plan) doesn't seem to be costing me anything - most
of the time the exit condition is either solved or all the parts overly
aggressively locked up on min_part_hours.  So far, it mostly seemds if
the thing is going to balance this round it'll get it in the first
couple of shakes.

Challenge #3 Crazy replica2part2dev tables
==========================================

I think there's lots of ways "scars" can build up a ring which can
result in very particular replica2part2dev tables that are physically
difficult to dig out of.  It's repairing these scars that will take
multiple rebalances to resolve.

... but at this point ...

... lacking a counter example ...

I've been able to close up all the edge cases I was able to find.  It
may not be quick, but progress will be made.

Basically my strategy just required a better understanding of how
previous algorithms were able to *mostly* keep things moving by brute
forcing the whole mess with a bunch of randomness.  Then when we detect
our "elegant" careful part selection isn't making progress - we can fall
back to same old tricks.

Validation
==========

We validate against duplicate part replica assignment after rebalance
and raise an ERROR if we detect more than one replica of a part assigned
to the same device.

In order to meet that requirement we have to have as many devices as
replicas, so attempting to rebalance with too few devices w/o changing
your replica_count is also an ERROR not a warning.

Random Thoughts
===============

As usual with rings, the test diff can be hard to reason about -
hopefully I've added enough comments to assure future me that these
assertions are make sense.

Despite being a large rewrite of a lot of important code, the existing
code is know to have failed us.  This change fixes a critical bug that's
trivial to reproduce in a critical component of the system.

There's probably a bunch of error messages and exit status stuff that's
not as helpful as it could be considering the new behaviors.

Change-Id: I1bbe7be38806fc1c8b9181a722933c18a6c76e05
Closes-Bug: #1452431

commit_message:
Put part-replicas where they go

It's harder than it sounds.  There was really three challenges.

Challenge #1 Initial Assignment
===============================

Before starting to assign parts on this new shiny ring you've
constructed, maybe we'll pause for a moment up front and consider the
lay of the land.  This process is called the replica_plan.

The replica_plan approach is separating part assignment failures into
two modes:

 1) we considered the cluster topology and it's weights and came up with
    the wrong plan

 2) we failed to execute on the plan

I failed at both parts plenty of times before I got it this close.  I'm
sure a counter example still exists, but when we find it the new helper
methods will let us reason about where things went wrong.

Challenge #2 Fixing Placement
=============================

With a sound plan in hand, it's much easier to fail to execute on it the
less material you have to execute with - so we gather up as many parts
as we can - as long as we think we can find them a better home.

Picking the right parts for gather is a black art - when you notice a
balance is slow it's because it's spending so much time iterating over
replica2part2dev trying to decide just the right parts to gather.

The replica plan can help at least in the gross dispersion collection to
gather up the worst offenders first before considering balance.  I think
trying to avoid picking up parts that are stuck to the tier before
falling into a forced grab on anything over parts_wanted helps with
stability generally - but depending on where the parts_wanted are in
relation to the full devices it's pretty easy pick up something that'll
end up really close to where it started.

I tried to break the gather methods into smaller pieces so it looked
like I knew what I was doing.

Going with a MAXIMUM gather iteration instead of balance (which doesn't
reflect the replica_plan) doesn't seem to be costing me anything - most
of the time the exit condition is either solved or all the parts overly
aggressively locked up on min_part_hours.  So far, it mostly seemds if
the thing is going to balance this round it'll get it in the first
couple of shakes.

Challenge #3 Crazy replica2part2dev tables
==========================================

I think there's lots of ways "scars" can build up a ring which can
result in very particular replica2part2dev tables that are physically
difficult to dig out of.  It's repairing these scars that will take
multiple rebalances to resolve.

... but at this point ...

... lacking a counter example ...

I've been able to close up all the edge cases I was able to find.  It
may not be quick, but progress will be made.

Basically my strategy just required a better understanding of how
previous algorithms were able to *mostly* keep things moving by brute
forcing the whole mess with a bunch of randomness.  Then when we detect
our "elegant" careful part selection isn't making progress - we can fall
back to same old tricks.

Validation
==========

We validate against duplicate part replica assignment after rebalance
and raise an ERROR if we detect more than one replica of a part assigned
to the same device.

In order to meet that requirement we have to have as many devices as
replicas, so attempting to rebalance with too few devices w/o changing
your replica_count is also an ERROR not a warning.

Random Thoughts
===============

As usual with rings, the test diff can be hard to reason about -
hopefully I've added enough comments to assure future me that these
assertions make sense.

Despite being a large rewrite of a lot of important code, the existing
code is known to have failed us.  This change fixes a critical bug that's
trivial to reproduce in a critical component of the system.

There's probably a bunch of error messages and exit status stuff that's
not as helpful as it could be considering the new behaviors.

Change-Id: I1bbe7be38806fc1c8b9181a722933c18a6c76e05
Closes-Bug: #1452431

commit_message:
Scheduler: honor the glance metadata for hypervisor details

The scheduler would not honor the glance image metadata for
'hypervisor_type' and 'hypervisor_version_requires'. This was due
to the fact that this was not part if the image_meta object.

Change-Id: I03742cc9330814e2758184d8189a5be93a2b978b
Closes-bug: #1523503
(cherry picked from commit f33dfa0647f0cd289bce19f7c06b3d0a88070a92)

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-11-12 22:40:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Convert headers to lower-case when parsing metadata

In urllib3 1.11.0 (and consequently, requests 2.8.0) handling was added
to preserve the casing of headers as they arrived over the wire. This
means that when iterating over a CaseInsensitiveDict from requests (as
we do in _image_meta_from_headers) we no longer get keys that are
already all lowercase. As a result, we need to ensure that the header
key is lowercased before checking its properties.

Change-Id: I61d73763a2cc42f9af8df972095afa8e3c5e8267
Closes-bug: #1476770

commit_message:
Convert headers to lower-case when parsing metadata

In urllib3 1.11.0 (and consequently, requests 2.8.0) handling was added
to preserve the casing of headers as they arrived over the wire. This
means that when iterating over a CaseInsensitiveDict from requests (as
we do in _image_meta_from_headers) we no longer get keys that are
already all lowercase. As a result, we need to ensure that the header
key is lowercased before checking its properties.

Co-Authored-By: Steve Lewis <stevelle@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I61d73763a2cc42f9af8df972095afa8e3c5e8267
Closes-bug: #1476770

[{'created': '2015-11-08 15:25:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Created new version of assignment driver interface

In preparation for removing a series of driver methods in
the rationalization of assignment in follow-on patches, we
first create a V9 version of the driver interface. In this
patch, of course, both V8 and V9 are identical.

WORK IN PROGRESS (DO NOT MERGE)

So I think this is the first time we have actually made a new
driver version - so I was kind of shooting in the dark. Is this
what we had in mind? Currently this blows up big time since:

1) Our SQL database fixtures scans the tree and loads all the
modules at the start - and didn't allow for us having multiple
versions of modules. I tried to fix that by passing it the
versions you want to run.  This works (sort of) and you can run
tox - test_backend_sql.SQLIdentityV8 successfully. However, if you
run the whole of the SQL tests is fails since you try and reload
a second version of the module

2) Someone added some funky backend assertion code in our LDAP
test - which now fail to match the right driver.  Haven't yet
looked at how to fix that up.

Can anyone shed light on how we are meant to be doing this?

Partially Implements: blueprint blueprint assignment-manager-cleanup
Change-Id: Iefa13b64084b8e71c881ae08e1ec434d24756c17

first create a V9 version of the driver interface. In this
patch, of course, both V8 and V9 are identical.

WORK IN PROGRESS (DO NOT MERGE) BUT PLEASE DO REVIEW

So I think this is the first time we have actually made a new
driver version - so I was kind of shooting in the dark. Is this
what we had in mind? What I have done is:

1) Copy the sql and ldap V8 drivers into their own directory
2) Increased the version of the (new) standard driver to V9
3) Created tests that run the standard sql/ldap Identity tests
against the V8 driver to show, going forward, it is still working.
Since we assume that we never change the sqlalchemy models during
a test run, this turned out to be slight more complex than
anticipated - so created a new tox envlist target for legacy
drivers.

TO DO:

Someone added some funky backend assertion code in our LDAP
tests - which now fail to match the right driver when we use the
legacy driver.  Haven't yet looked at how to fix that up.

Partially Implements: blueprint blueprint assignment-manager-cleanup

first create a V9 version of the driver interface. In this
patch, both V8 and V9 are identical.

To create the new V9 driver we:

1) Copied the sql and ldap V8 drivers into their own directory
2) Increased the version of the (new) standard driver to V9
3) Created tests that run the standard sql/ldap Identity tests
against the V8 driver to show, going forward, it is still working.
Since we assume that we never change the sqlalchemy models during
a test run, this turned out to be slight more complex than
anticipated - so created a new tox envlist target for legacy
drivers. Some changes were also needed in the backend assertion
checking for LDAP, to allow for legacy drivers.

Partially Implements: blueprint assignment-manager-cleanup
Change-Id: Iefa13b64084b8e71c881ae08e1ec434d24756c17

commit_message:
Create new version of assignment driver interface

In preparation for removing a series of driver methods in
the rationalization of assignment in follow-on patches, we
first create a V9 version of the driver interface. In this
patch, both V8 and V9 are identical.

To create the new V9 driver we:

1) Copy the sql V8 driver into its own directory to provide a
test for support of a legacy driver
2) Increase the version of the (new) standard driver to V9
3) Create a wrapper for V8 legacy drivers, so that the latest
manager can be driver version-less
4) Create tests that run the standard sql Identity tests
against the V8 driver to show, going forward, it is still working.
Since our existing test strategy assumes that we never change the
sqlalchemy models during a test run, this turned out to be slight
more complex than anticipated - so a new tox envlist target for legacy
drivers is added.

Partially Implements: blueprint assignment-manager-cleanup
Change-Id: Iefa13b64084b8e71c881ae08e1ec434d24756c17

[{'created': '2015-10-13 04:44:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'export DATABASES_TO_SAVE for save-state

I noticed this in I45894911c0ee9cd6c9b142d6192350269873d82f where the

commit_message:
export DATABASES_TO_SAVE for save-state

I noticed this in I45894911c0ee9cd6c9b142d6192350269873d82f where the
"old" database isn't dumped.  This seems to be because "save-state"
calls inc/upgrade:save_mysql_dbs, but it doesn't have access to
DATABASES_TO_SAVE because it's not exported.  An additional trick is
that save-state includes inc/upgrade, so be sure not to overwrite the
variable as blank.

Depends-On: I45894911c0ee9cd6c9b142d6192350269873d82f
Change-Id: I49626dcc277497eaf66d4d998ba8b2655293d28f

Refactor: Use Federation constants where possible

There was a couple of FIXME notes (from
If5857a6ee4c7c527929069b25beab40f4c5d87e2) asking
to use federation constants rather than hardcoded
string values.

This patch fixes those notes.

commit_message:
Remove exposure of routers at package level

Keystone API routers are exposed at their package
level (in __init__.py files). This causes them to
be unnecessarily executed each time something
whithin that package is used.

For example, simply importing
keystone.federation.constants would make the
federation routers code to be executed.

This patch remove routers exposure from package
level and import them directly in services.py,
which is the single place that needs them.

Change-Id: If68184c871ac77659ad2e64aa5f0aafac7a4bf70

commit_message:
Remove invalid TODO related to bug 1265071

There is a TODO note at the SQL catalog backend
saying that not all SQL entities should require
an 'extra' attribute. This is reported as bug
1265071.

This patch removes that note, since the bug has
now been fixed.

Related-Bug: #1265071

Change-Id: Id42e144706e60d599b86dbe17175fe6cd9650604

commit_message:
Revert "Revert "OVS agent reacts to events instead of polling""

The original change had to be reverted because it caused
tests failing in the gate. The failures were due to the
fact that when a port was not ready, an exception was
thrown to trigger a full resync of the agent. This
behavior was meant to be temporary and was fixed in a
dependent patch that was not merged though. This revert
moves the handling of not ready ports in this patch.
It also refactors the unit tests a bit.

This reverts commit e7270d9505fe09ec6d687e7796a814bf883b5416.

Change-Id: I6574cef3c95525ace6a98cf968ee159190681394

revisions:

The api was incorrectly omitting the time
in the where clause if the value was 0, so
check for None instead.

Change-Id: Ic7c225924efce42aae21eb4a909fb877fa6b171f
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Fix stats bug for start_time = 1970-01-01

The api was incorrectly omitting the time
in the where clause if the value was 0, so
check for None instead.

Change-Id: Ic7c225924efce42aae21eb4a909fb877fa6b171f

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-08-11 21:32:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Add persistence to the RequestSpec object

In order to use the request spec for an instance boot during later
scheduling operations, like resize/migrate, it needs to be persisted.
This adds a db migration to store the request spec and methods to the
object to create/save/get the request spec.

The RequestSpec object is also important for cells v2 so that boot
requests can have their information persisted before the creation of an
instance record in the database.

Change-Id: I94cd50ad29e10eb320d1d78f3081db6519815ff9
Implements: bp persist-request-spec

commit_message:
Add persistence to the RequestSpec object

In order to use the request spec for an instance boot during later
scheduling operations, like resize/migrate, it needs to be persisted.
This adds a db migration to store the request spec and methods to the
object to create/save/get the request spec.

The RequestSpec object is also important for cells v2 so that boot
requests can have their information persisted before the creation of an
instance record in the database.

Change-Id: I94cd50ad29e10eb320d1d78f3081db6519815ff9
Implements: bp persist-request-spec

subject: Clarify when the blueprint should be created
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 360, 'name': 'Dan Prince', 'email': 'dprince@redhat.com', 'username': 'dan-prince'}, {'_account_id': 4190, 'name': 'lifeless', 'email': 'robertc@robertcollins.net', 'username': 'lifeless'}, {'_account_id': 6796, 'name': 'Giulio Fidente', 'email': 'gfidente@redhat.com', 'username': 'gfidente'}, {'_account_id': 6928, 'name': 'Ben Nemec', 'email': 'openstack@nemebean.com', 'username': 'bnemec'}, {'_account_id': 7144, 'name': 'James Slagle', 'email': 'jslagle@redhat.com', 'username': 'slagle'}, {'_account_id': 8399, 'name': 'Jay Dobies', 'email': 'jason.dobies@redhat.com', 'username': 'jdob'}, {'_account_id': 9453, 'name': 'James Polley', 'email': 'jp@jamezpolley.com', 'username': 'tchaypo'}, {'_account_id': 10035, 'name': 'greghaynes', 'email': 'greg@greghaynes.net', 'username': 'greghaynes'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2014-06-23 08:29:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Clarify when the blueprint should be created

Several commenters on Id9addc65f0d2ed519ce4b3edbd561ed660a2786e have
been confused by the fact that the spec includes a reference to a
launchpad blueprint URL that doesn't exist.

This is even more confusing for reviewers of changes like
I9649ee74ebaf62b6b929b28243a07c789a08867c which reference the
blueprint URL as an explanation of why the change is being made - when
the link is broken reviewers have no context that lets them evaluate
the change.

To prevent this being a problem, I've added a note to template.rst
explaining that the blueprint should be created early, and have a
pointer to the change so that reviewers can follow the progress of the
spec.

This change is not itself a spec; it's a change to the process of
creating specs; but I feel as though the same approval process we use
for specs would make sense to use for changing the we suggest creating
specs.

Change-Id: I57bf5e0d73c63120259973515ea26593a2776ba2
", 'number': 1}, {'created': '2014-08-05 00:59:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Remove references to blueprints

This change is not itself a spec; it's a change to the process of
creating specs; but I feel as though the same approval process we use
for specs would make sense to use for changing the we suggest creating
specs.

There seems to be broad consensus within the group that we don't like
the Blueprints UI and would prefer to avoid using it wherever possible.

This change updates our docs to remove suggestion of creating a
blueprint. The final spec will be available on specs.openstack.org and
changes can be handled via the usual git approval process.

Change-Id: I57bf5e0d73c63120259973515ea26593a2776ba2

commit_message:
Clarify when the blueprint should be created

Several commenters on Id9addc65f0d2ed519ce4b3edbd561ed660a2786e have
been confused by the fact that the spec includes a reference to a
launchpad blueprint URL that doesn't exist.

This is even more confusing for reviewers of changes like
I9649ee74ebaf62b6b929b28243a07c789a08867c which reference the
blueprint URL as an explanation of why the change is being made - when
the link is broken reviewers have no context that lets them evaluate
the change.

To prevent this being a problem, I've added a note to template.rst
explaining that the blueprint should be created early, and have a
pointer to the change so that reviewers can follow the progress of the
spec.

This change is not itself a spec; it's a change to the process of
creating specs; but I feel as though the same approval process we use
for specs would make sense to use for changing the we suggest creating
specs.

Change-Id: I57bf5e0d73c63120259973515ea26593a2776ba2

commit_message:
Add Rally to networking-ovn

This adds the needed infrastructure to connect networking-ovn
with Rally benchmarking.
A relevant job will be defined to run Neutron with OVN with
the ovn.yaml jobs.
It is easy to defined OVN specific plugins and change the
scenarios run by Rally for OVN using the added files in this
patch.

Change-Id: I7c6a518ba8fb01725cb7a32f5e62062afc16f632

[{'created': '2015-12-01 18:52:05.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/volume/drivers/netapp/eseries/library.py', 'cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/netapp/eseries/test_library.py'], 'message': 'NetApp: Cleanup if E-Series volume create fails

that a volume in a partial state has been created.
When Openstack comes back re-attempting the creation
operation it fails because the partial volume with
the name already exists.

Solution: When there is a failure creating a volume,
check if a partial volume was created and delete it
so any retry will be successful and the storage device

', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
NetApp: Cleanup if E-Series volume create fails

The creation of a volume may fail in such a manner
that a volume in a partial state has been created.
When Openstack comes back re-attempting the creation
operation it fails because the partial volume with
the name already exists.

Solution: When there is a failure creating a volume,
check if a partial volume was created and delete it
so any retry will be successful and the storage device
does not contain any dead volumes.

Closes-Bug: 1506940
Change-Id: Id93527a4cab314f27a13d8c08b772fed538d1092
(cherry picked from commit a4bcb1e11bf48207c81e42ba3b9c96f5e13d3ef6)

commit_message:
Use ironic-agent for source-repositories

I recently built a ramdisk for IPA and was confused by
the fact that the source-repositories name did not
match the element name. (this is a convention,
confusing when they don't match but certainly not
required).

This patch makes it so you can use DIB_REPOREF_ironic_agent to
customize the IPA ramdisk sources when building ramdisks.

For backwards compat if DIB_REPOREF_agent is set it automatically
sets the new DIB_REPOREF_ironic_agent to that value as well.

Change-Id: I082d989d0d85601f5984dc7c3767b8d66a3d5438

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-12-02 18:11:43.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/api/contrib/quotas.py', 'cinder/tests/unit/api/contrib/test_quotas.py'], 'message': 'Fix delete quota of subprojects

This patch aims to fix the bug in which cinder raises
an error when performing a delete quota operation in
a subproject.

Steps to reproduce:
- Create a project A in keystone (e.g openstack project create A);
- Create a project B in keystone with A as its parent (e.g openstack
  project create B --property parent_id=<id of project A>);
- Update the quota value of A (e.g. openstack quota set
  <id of project A> --volume 5)
- Update the quota value of B (e.g. openstack quota set
  <id of project B> --volume 2)
- Try to delete the quota of B (e.g. cinder quota-delete
  <id of project B>)

Change-Id: Id1a749433c3679f1b2adf87ea0a280366c5e4a15
Closes-bug: #1496058
(cherry picked from commit 9a668a0a48135c423a4deda23bb161f6b917ac39)
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Fix delete quota of subprojects

This patch aims to fix the bug in which cinder raises
an error when performing a delete quota operation in
a subproject.

Steps to reproduce:
- Create a project A in keystone (e.g openstack project create A);
- Create a project B in keystone with A as its parent (e.g openstack
  project create B --property parent_id=<id of project A>);
- Update the quota value of A (e.g. openstack quota set
  <id of project A> --volume 5)
- Update the quota value of B (e.g. openstack quota set
  <id of project B> --volume 2)
- Try to delete the quota of B (e.g. cinder quota-delete
  <id of project B>)

Change-Id: Id1a749433c3679f1b2adf87ea0a280366c5e4a15
Closes-bug: #1496058
(cherry picked from commit 9a668a0a48135c423a4deda23bb161f6b917ac39)

commit_message:
Update router interface add/delete for ovsdb ovn-nb schema change

The latest ovsdb schema change [1] enables us to use lrouter port
name as router-port option in corresponding lswitch port. This
change is to update the logic accordingly. With this change the
two operations, adding lrouter port and updating peering lswitch
port are combined to a single transaction.

[1] https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/commit/0000744721bab30bd0db538fb3bc412137d5249f

Closes-bug: 1522540

Change-Id: I6a9f1328e8f6a7cb060dc377e14e3cdf6f014bb9

commit_message:
Refactor OVS-agent tunnel config validate

This change transforms validate_local_ip into a sub-method of
validate_tunnel_config and raises directly SystemExit instead of
indirectly.

commit_message:
Replace os.path.join() for URLs

Since os.path.join() is OS-dependent, it should not be used for creating
URLs. This patch replaces the use of os.path.join() in
nova/api/openstack with common.url_join(), which uses the more correct
"/".join(), while preserving the behavior of removing duplicate slashes
inside the URL and adding a trailing slash with an empty final element.
It also adds some tests to ensure that the generate_href() method in
nova/api/openstack/compute/views/versions.py works after the refactoring
to use common.url_join()

Closes-Bug: 1489627
Change-Id: I32948dd1fcf0839b34e446d9e4b08f9c39d17c8f

commit_message:
Fixes TLS processing in the rest driver

The rest driver was not using updated cert utils to
handle processing of TLS certificates and would cause failures.

Also updates build_pem to be py34 compliant.

Change-Id: I05db39ff673083649735434f8e4cc710086ffd54
Closes-Bug: #1507723
(cherry picked from commit I05db39ff673083649735434f8e4cc710086ffd54)

commit_message:
Remove version from setup.cfg

Per [1] we now want to use the git repository for knowing the version
instead of just trying to modify the setup.cfg file.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-November/080692.html

Depends-On: Ifa41ef5b856c2726c165a51944069dc1ac3a16cc
Change-Id: I884d1196f0320d85257f521591d36ed7cfbc8013

subject: Checks percent_of_overlap when one boundary is set
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-12-03 15:57:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Checks percent_of_overlap when one boundary is set

Aggregation across metrics have different behavior depending
of if boundary are set and if needed_percent_of_overlap is set.

If boundaries are not set, Carbonara makes the aggregation only with points
at timestamp present in all timeseries.

But when boundaries are set, Carbonara expects that we have certain
percent of timestamps common between timeseries, this percent is controlled
by needed_percent_of_overlap (defaulted with 100%).

This change fixes a weird behavior when only one boundary is set,
the needed_percent_of_overlap wasn't checked.

Change-Id: Ifc85a9004e864d14d42fd482ec144e4d27dd615b
Closes-bug: #1522434

commit_message:
Checks percent_of_overlap when one boundary is set

Aggregation across metrics have different behavior depending
on if boundary are set and if needed_percent_of_overlap is set.

If boundaries are not set, Carbonara makes the aggregation only with points
at timestamp present in all timeseries.

But when boundaries are set, Carbonara expects that we have certain
percent of timestamps common between timeseries, this percent is controlled
by needed_percent_of_overlap (defaulted with 100%).

This change fixes a weird behavior when only one boundary is set,
the needed_percent_of_overlap wasn't checked.

Change-Id: Ifc85a9004e864d14d42fd482ec144e4d27dd615b
Closes-bug: #1522434

[{'created': '2015-12-08 11:22:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Remove Neutron FWaaS static example configuration files

Oslo config generator was introduced in patch [1] to
automatically generate the sample Neutron FWaaS configuration
files.

This patch removes the static example configuration files from
the repository as they are now redundant.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/251974/

DocImpact: Update the docs that LBaaS no longer includes static example
configuration files. Instead, use tools/generate_config_file_samples.sh
to generate them and the files generated now end with .sample extension.

Change-Id: I31be3295606ba25929e9af9f40a035ff2b615234
Partially-Implements: blueprint autogen-neutron-conf-file
Partial-bug: #1199963

commit_message:
Remove Neutron FWaaS static example configuration files

Oslo config generator was introduced in patch [1] to
automatically generate the sample Neutron FWaaS configuration
files.

This patch removes the static example configuration files from
the repository as they are now redundant.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/251974/

DocImpact: Update the docs that FWaaS no longer includes static example
configuration files. Instead, use tools/generate_config_file_samples.sh
to generate them and the files generated now end with .sample extension.

Change-Id: I31be3295606ba25929e9af9f40a035ff2b615234
Partially-Implements: blueprint autogen-neutron-conf-file
Partial-bug: #1199963
Depends-On: Ic8208850a27408c8fbeed80ecdb43345aa7dfaa4

commit_message:
Block oslo.messaging 3.1.0 since it breaks Ironic

oslo.messaging change I21d76abf1c30b9e89cb8a6c20d1c0cc79cd83a3f was
released in 3.1.0 and due to debtcollector bug 1520397 it breaks Ironic
loading it's request context serializer.

That was worked around in Ironic on master (mitaka) in commit
37d36f1536944de38a0f7a726e625b893088e1be but that doesn't fix Ironic in
stable/liberty, and we aren't going to backport that workaround to
stable/liberty.

So we need to fix oslo.messaging (either revert the deprecation change
or remove the usage of debtcollector) and release a fix there to fix
stable/liberty, but we still have to block the broken 3.1.0 release.

Related-Bug: #1524041

Change-Id: I3c5a9851ada30b6d7470113014b542b550a4ae8b

subject: Add docker_images_redhat.yaml build-images file
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-07-09 02:21:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Add docker_images_redhat.yaml build-images file

This patch adds a file to help build the heat docker "agent"
base image. We intend to use an image like this to help provision
a docker atomic host for TripleO. It should allow us to
run os-collect-config, various plugins, among other things.

Building this image with DIB is a really handy way to tap
into existing elements for TripleO which already support
the things we need. The downside is that the generated
image is going to be a base image... so there may still
be a case for building a similar image with Dockerfile's
as well. Still... having the the capability to work
with existing elements should significantly speed
up development because we can make use of more robust
elements like source-repositories, etc.

Because of how the docker base element works (and isn't a full
operating system) have had to define elements like yum, and
redhat-common within this config file. As such it is Red Hat
specific.

We also exclude the 'base' element to keep things a bit smaller.

Change-Id: I195c0ef8b844a5fd28a1f4ba465d975787775734

commit_message:
Add docker_images_redhat.yaml build-images file

This patch adds a file to help build the heat docker "agent"
base image. We intend to use an image like this to help provision
a docker atomic host for TripleO. It should allow us to
run os-collect-config, various plugins, among other things.

Building this image with DIB is a really handy way to tap
into existing elements for TripleO which already support
the things we need. The downside is that the generated
image is going to be a base image... so there may still
be a case for building a similar image with Dockerfile's
as well. Still... having the the capability to work
with existing elements should significantly speed
up development because we can make use of more robust
elements like source-repositories, etc.

Because of how the docker base element works (and isn't a full
operating system) have had to define elements like yum, and
redhat-common within this config file. As such it is Red Hat
specific.

We also exclude the 'base' element to keep things a bit smaller.

Change-Id: I195c0ef8b844a5fd28a1f4ba465d975787775734

subject: Add support for generic controller validations
revisions:

parameter (currently must be customized via default_parameters in
the Heat environment.) This parameter provides a means to plug
in a custom shell script which can be used to validate

commit_message:
Add support for generic controller validations

This patch wires in support for a generic controller validations
via a shell script.

Use of this requires a new heat-config-script element in order
to actually execute the shell script on the node via os-refresh-config.

Co-Authored-By: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ib6f1153f8c2b857c1b2b5c9172a9836da70fe0ce

commit_message:
Stop checking if listener exists when uploading cert

The cert is being uplaoded in the flow BEFORE a listener is being
created. So creating a TLS load balancer will always result in an
error. This removes that check.

Closes-Bug: 1507723

Change-Id: If8d6de33ef7a4e71bdf80115da889da6f0535736
(cherry picked from commit If8d6de33ef7a4e71bdf80115da889da6f0535736)

commit_message:
Add class B3 and an example for C1 to the taxonomy

Be more explicit that OSSA does not cover vulnerabilities in
experimental features, backends and drivers by adding a new class B3
for these in the taxonomy. Also clarify that vulnerabilities relying
on UUID guessing are considered impractical, as an example for class
C1.

Change-Id: Ie73dfb0358913e6bdfeba56e6105f8156382d042

commit_message:
Add ceilometer constructor to known constructors

In porting ospurge to use get_legacy_client, it became clear that
the ceilometer client constructor was missing. Add it.

subject: add 'tempest' in puppet-openstack-integration jobs
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-12-08 20:02:42.000000000', 'files': ['jenkins/jobs/puppet-module-jobs.yaml', 'zuul/layout.yaml'], 'message': "add 'tempest' in puppet-openstack-integration jobs

To have the puppet integration jobs part of Health [1] project, we want
logstash about to read subunit-files.
So we need to rename the jobs to match this job filter:
job-filter: '.*(tempest|grenade)-dsvm.*'

That way, we will be able to see the subunit results on [1].
Puppet group already did the necessary to prepare the subunit files, we
just miss this patch to actually rename the jobs.

[1] http://status.openstack.org/openstack-health/#/

Change-Id: Ia41489a913d2adfc00b5f0d9177d1e810e95eec8
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
add 'tempest' in puppet-openstack-integration jobs

To have the puppet integration jobs part of Health [1] project, we want
logstash about to read subunit-files.
So we need to rename the jobs to match this job filter:
job-filter: '.*(tempest|grenade)-dsvm.*'

That way, we will be able to see the subunit results on [1].
Puppet group already did the necessary to prepare the subunit files, we
just miss this patch to actually rename the jobs.

[1] http://status.openstack.org/openstack-health/#/

Change-Id: Ia41489a913d2adfc00b5f0d9177d1e810e95eec8

The previous commit moved all the scheduler options to a central

Blueprint centralize-config-options

commit_message:
Let users restrict stack-update scope

A spec describing a new option for stack update that will let users
protect certain resources from being destroyed/replaced in that update.

Change-Id: Ib29abad41d03e7054debd346ad9ee333421b6b21
BP: stack-update-restrict

subject: test requirements with grenade multinode
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-12-09 16:26:04.000000000', 'files': ['zuul/layout.yaml'], 'message': 'test requirements with grenade multinode

We only have a single voting multinode job, which is the grenade
partial upgrade job. Things like backportability of objects, and
actually going across a network get tested here in ways that no other
job tests. We should also use this test for requirements.

Change-Id: I9e6ff2e79ab1a59b7d1e4661b2f2030d8e453581
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
test requirements with grenade multinode

We only have a single voting multinode job, which is the grenade
partial upgrade job. Things like backportability of objects, and
actually going across a network get tested here in ways that no other
job tests. We should also use this test for requirements.

Change-Id: I9e6ff2e79ab1a59b7d1e4661b2f2030d8e453581

", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Adding oneview.common tests for some method not well tested

This is the first of a patch series to improve OneView driver unit
testing. There are some functions at oneview.common that need more
test cases. This change add test cases to cover specific scenarios
for 'get_oneview_info' and '_verify_node_info' functions.

Change-Id: Id1246bc5366018d642874bfbde23b6b13763f322

commit_message:
devstack: Switch back to ovs master.

The conntrack kernel backport has been merged back into ovs master, so
we can drop the use of a custom branch.

Change-Id: I049525257cf615b60965bdb655e884c4b7316e0d
Signed-off-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>

commit_message:
devstack: Update list of kernel modules to load.

Update the list of kernel modules to explicitly load before openvswitch
to resolve some errors I've seen on different failures.  Related, if
openvswitch still fails to load, get dmesg output.

Change-Id: Iadcb1feed89fb53333724edc0df71335eda81a3f
Signed-off-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>

subject: iPXE: use set arithmetic to increment the value of a variable
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-11-12 10:18:54.000000000', 'files': ['ironic/drivers/modules/boot.ipxe'], 'message': 'iPXE: use set arithmetic to increment the value of a variable

The "inc" command doesn't exist on really old iPXE ROMs so we need to
create a basic arithmetic mechanism using set to do it.

Note: I find this patch really ugly, I would prefer people to just
update their iPXE ROM instead. But I'm putting it up and leaving for
comments anyway.

Change-Id: Idcf13d8a6124a5b0b26a7c3b959d3749f2383933
Closes-Bug: #1507738
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
iPXE: use set arithmetic to increment the value of a variable

The "inc" command doesn't exist on really old iPXE ROMs so we need to
create a basic arithmetic mechanism using set to do it.

Note: I find this patch really ugly, I would prefer people to just
update their iPXE ROM instead. But I'm putting it up and leaving for
comments anyway.

Change-Id: Idcf13d8a6124a5b0b26a7c3b959d3749f2383933
Closes-Bug: #1507738

commit_message:
Explicitly use asyncio protocol for websockets

The new default for txaio (dependency of autobahn) requires that you
specify how you want websocket connections to be managed (asyncio or
twisted) and raises an exception if you don't make a choice.

commit_message:
Implementing DevStack support for networking-sfc

This patch implements devstack plugin changes for deploying
networking-sfc solution via devStack.

Note: Download all sfc code and do
./unstack.sh and ./stack.sh

Change-Id: Id9453685c81a7bfdf7e72ce9f0dba0e307333037
Co-Authored-By: vikram.choudhary <vikram.choudhary@huawei.com>

commit_message:
Included namespace_prefix logic in toscaparser

if namespace_prefix is provided in imports, the full name will be
namespace_prefix.type while importing type definition from namespace.

Partially Implements: blueprint tosca-namespaces

Change-Id: I8fb43a6db2fc040713f41c75a80e27abbe451ea1

[{'created': '2015-12-02 22:34:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Address potential races in SolidFire VAG.

While building the initial volume access group solution I realized there were
race conditions present. This patch attempts to address those by being far
more careful during VAG creation and removal. Tracking multiattach volume

conditions so instead multiattach volumes are treated differently and are only

Change-Id: I80034cdf759295c8d379c02ed9e42659590b41a9
", 'number': 1}, {'created': '2015-12-03 19:01:51.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/volume/drivers/solidfire.py', 'cinder/tests/unit/test_solidfire.py'], 'message': "Address potential races in SolidFire VAG

Change-Id: I80034cdf759295c8d379c02ed9e42659590b41a9

commit_message:
Address potential races in SolidFire VAG

While building the initial volume access group solution I realized there were
race conditions present. This patch attempts to address those by being far
more careful during VAG creation and removal. Tracking multiattach volume
detaches around VAG volume removal introduced all sorts of future race
conditions so instead multiattach volumes are treated differently and are only
removed from VAGs on volume removal. Not ideal but it'll get the job done.

Think I covered all the new branches with unit tests. Complexity was introduced
but it should be worth it due to the safety that was also introduced.

Change-Id: I80034cdf759295c8d379c02ed9e42659590b41a9

commit_message:
fix pecan _lookup usage

_lookup routing in pecan is expected to be an object method. we
incorrectly set it to static which throws a few warnings. this patch
fixes it.

Closes-Bug: #1521283
Change-Id: I0911cbe830eef84af613e08dc9495109d27a1646
(cherry picked from commit 96e43af961a3d1722425e6f03822f4a217c68c08)

subject: fix expunge_metrics method
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-12-04 14:51:14.000000000', 'files': ['gnocchi/tests/test_indexer.py', 'gnocchi/indexer/sqlalchemy.py'], 'message': "fix expunge_metrics method

expunge_metrics method does not work properly. it uses list_metrics
from indexer to get metrics with status == 'delete'. this makes sense
but list_metrics itself is hardcoded to always search for 'active'
status. because of that, the query will always be look for status ==
'active' and status == 'delete' which can't happen so it never finds
any match.

Change-Id: I318fa5b4642a187776dce23ee9a933a5f852c4f8
(cherry picked from commit f6a61a289dfe20bd8cf1ce597ac415323ddf8c1a)
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
fix expunge_metrics method

expunge_metrics method does not work properly. it uses list_metrics
from indexer to get metrics with status == 'delete'. this makes sense
but list_metrics itself is hardcoded to always search for 'active'
status. because of that, the query will always be look for status ==
'active' and status == 'delete' which can't happen so it never finds
any match.

Change-Id: I318fa5b4642a187776dce23ee9a933a5f852c4f8
(cherry picked from commit f6a61a289dfe20bd8cf1ce597ac415323ddf8c1a)

commit_message:
fix error in alembic when upgrade postgresql

ALTER TYPE ... ADD cannot run inside a transaction block,
therefore we use another way to update it.

Change-Id: I8c6f62b7642917a2ea1bc0280e41261797aca172
Closes-Bug: #1520777
(cherry picked from commit 20418cd339af775842e84c2b6d2a820289888f00)

commit_message:
Update Liberty SHA's - 9 Dec 2015

Updates all repo SHAs to open up work on 12.0.3

This also includes a move of the Aodh repository to
playbooks/defaults/repo_packages/openstack_services.yml
as it now has a stable/liberty branch, and an update
of the policy.json template based on the one available
in the stable branch.

Change-Id: If0114d8f04cff8203f3ac36c71b8d19f9909708c

commit_message:
Implements proper UUID format for the ComputeAPITestCase

Currently unittests are using non valid UUID format for the
FieldType UUID. This is used across many objects.

This is preparation work to add UUID validation in the
oslo_versionedobjects/fields.py.

Without this change adding validation will cause tests to fail.

Change-Id: Iaad96b4185d19055dff40450eab2a1818b7054a0

commit_message:
Change endpoint.url column type to String

Change endpoint.url column type from TEXT to VARCHAR, to be able to
include the url field in a unique constraint that avoids the creation of
duplicated endpoints.

Co-Authored-By: Raildo Mascena <raildo@lsd.ufcg.edu.br>

Change-Id: I4d9fdf53dd3f6be7e9b288fd95a12bc0b4dd81fc
Partial-Bug: 1376937

commit_message:
Fix Create Endpoint API Status Code

The v3 API returns 200 OK on endpoint creation. This patch fixes our
documentation to make it consistent.

Closes-Bug: #1522577

subject: Numerous debug messages due to iso8601 log level
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-12-08 20:47:21.000000000', 'files': ['ironic/common/service.py'], 'message': 'Numerous debug messages due to iso8601 log level

iso8601 is indirectly used by keystone client and removing
the log level iso8601=WARNING results in numerous debug messages.
This patch reverts iso8601=WARNING log level removal introduced
in 37816a0e63ed48ed3763e8c312fbb42c14b92167 commit.

Change-Id: I9367cc0f39e6f08b0cf437c02100c74c9bc126d2
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Numerous debug messages due to iso8601 log level

iso8601 is indirectly used by keystone client and removing
the log level iso8601=WARNING results in numerous debug messages.
This patch reverts iso8601=WARNING log level removal introduced
in 37816a0e63ed48ed3763e8c312fbb42c14b92167 commit.

Change-Id: I9367cc0f39e6f08b0cf437c02100c74c9bc126d2

commit_message:
tests: block when acquiring processing lock

In tests, not blocking when processing the data in background might
trigger a race condition since all the tests run in parallel on the same
database.

Change-Id: Id808f9e659f242fdaecd52cad08a6d00c96ac051

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-12-09 12:24:47.000000000', 'files': ['stack.sh'], 'message': "Simplify RDO install

We can just directly install the latest RDO repo rather than having to
keep this up-to-date.  I don't think there is actually much there we
need any more; there was a lot more coming from RDO in the centos6
days.  openvswitch is one big one, however.

(cherry picked from commit 1eca508c57dd987fa6f7a7e6f441096365e6892d)

Change-Id: Ibce834c3e76d71a770013cf1b469aa86396751b9
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Simplify RDO install

We can just directly install the latest RDO repo rather than having to
keep this up-to-date.  I don't think there is actually much there we
need any more; there was a lot more coming from RDO in the centos6
days.  openvswitch is one big one, however.

(cherry picked from commit 1eca508c57dd987fa6f7a7e6f441096365e6892d)

Change-Id: Ibce834c3e76d71a770013cf1b469aa86396751b9

commit_message:
Remove httpretty from requirements

We've had problems with this with packaging and pinning requirements.
requests-mock is a already accepted and used replacement so remove
httpretty in favour of that.

Change-Id: I2382c6a0425c98bf969127b2e11f9d6926e52c53

commit_message:
Skip keystone endpoint test due to bug 1522577

That bug reports that endpoint creation should
return HTTP 201 Created status code.

There is a tempest test checking the status
code is 200 OK. Such test is now skipped and
will be restored once keystone change [1] lands.

[1] Ic17a8cb0181bb864094b28edfee61e1e65c1ca93

Related-Bug: #1522577

Change-Id: I872d362f92b51ff785e8dd7602a8734a0762c96f

commit_message:
Python 3: fix a lot of tests

As of this commit, the following tests should now be working with Python 3:

- cinder.tests.unit.api.contrib.test_cgsnapshots
- cinder.tests.unit.api.contrib.test_scheduler_hints
- cinder.tests.unit.api.contrib.test_snapshot_actions
- cinder.tests.unit.api.contrib.test_snapshot_manage
- cinder.tests.unit.api.contrib.test_snapshot_unmanage
- cinder.tests.unit.api.contrib.test_volume_encryption_metadata
- cinder.tests.unit.api.contrib.test_volume_host_attribute
- cinder.tests.unit.api.contrib.test_volume_manage
- cinder.tests.unit.api.contrib.test_volume_migration_status_attribute
- cinder.tests.unit.api.contrib.test_volume_tenant_attribute
- cinder.tests.unit.api.contrib.test_volume_unmanage
- cinder.tests.unit.api.v2.test_volumes

Most changes in this patch:
- make sure that Request.body is set to bytes;
- replace jsonutils.dumps with jsonutils.dump_as_bytes;
- replace json.loads with oslo_serialization.jsonutils.loads;
- replace dict.iteritems with dict.items.

Partial-Implements: blueprint cinder-python3
Change-Id: Icbb96ff84b7012b58f7296eea4fbcd620e081614

commit_message:
Fix endpoint test related to bug 1522577

That bug reports that endpoint creation should
return HTTP 201 Created status code.

There was a tempest test checking the status
code which was skipped in the parent change [1].

This patch restores and fixes the check of status
code for endpoint creation.

[1] I872d362f92b51ff785e8dd7602a8734a0762c96f

Depends-On: Ic17a8cb0181bb864094b28edfee61e1e65c1ca93
Change-Id: I9fc4b224324e900a4bbe1b390ecb96bee2f6290c

commit_message:
Enable optional Python 3 support

Add USE_PYTHON3 and PYTHON3_VERSION variables to allow services to use
python 3 if they indicate support in their python package metadata.

Tested in Heat here -> I837c2fba682ab430d50e9f43913f2fed20325a7a.
Project config change to add a dedicated job to Heat is here -> I0837e62d6ccc66397a5e409f0961edd4be31f467

Change-Id: I079e18b58b214bf8362945c253d6d894ca8b1a6b

commit_message:
Fix create endpoint API status code

Both /v2.0 and /v3 APIs return 200 OK on endpoint
creation.

This patch both APIs to return HTTP 201 Created.

Closes-Bug: #1522577

Depends-On: I872d362f92b51ff785e8dd7602a8734a0762c96f
Change-Id: Ic17a8cb0181bb864094b28edfee61e1e65c1ca93

commit_message:
Allow choice of upstart or sysvinit

upstart was hardcoded as the means of start, stopping and reloading
of haproxy. Allow for sysvinit scripts and paths to handle haproxy.

This patch provides a configuration option to switch
between the defaultl upstart init scripts or sysvinit.

Change-Id: I9efe51c5a08d8e2268150d69ac25725c708dfb8e

commit_message:
Remove py26 from tox config

Support of py26 is dropped by manilaclient dependencies.
So, remove such job for manilaclient too.

Change-Id: I63d58d0054765b4ed965fc4795a61feca0cbf406
Closes-Bug: #1521941

Change-Id: I58689d2ae88979a1119475267998c09e18915083
Closes-Bug: #1524081

commit_message:
Fix timestamp in RBAC extension

The previous timestamp had an invalid TZ offset.
This patch just sets it to UTC like the others.

Change-Id: I58689d2ae88979a1119475267998c09e18915083
Closes-Bug: #1524081

commit_message:
Make MetadataProxyHandler configurable

Make MetadataProxyHandler configurable through metadata_agent.ini.
This allows vendors to extend the default MetadataProxyHandler.

Also add get_subnets method in MetadataPluginAPI class and
associated RPC unit test. The new method can be used by extended
MetadataProxyHandler classes to search subnets via plugin RPC.

DocImpact
UpgradeImpact

Closes-bug: #1518402
Change-Id: I910921e5e15bffef97d69283ca59b9785a5f6fe3

commit_message:
Moves get_agent_configurations to l2_agent

The moved method is only used in the l2_agent.

NOTE: this commit must not merge before the commit
I32451cba6933e88306a4308a07f3f0d1b81f626c. Otherwise,
it will break Hyper-V CI.

commit_message:
Enable Nova and Glance tempest tests

This commit resolves errors of nova, glance
tempest tests and enables them to run on gate.

It still skips neutron tests for now and will enabled
in other patch, as it needs some more investigation
to enable them.

Partial-Bug:#1486246
Change-Id: I5d69ed515496aa259833a3519c12197496afad2f

commit_message:
Validate image when create a Bay

For good user experience, we should validate Baymodel's image
in Bay creation. The following 3 conditions will be checked:
1. Image not existed - 404 Not Found
2. Found multiple images with same image name - 409 Conflict
3. Image 'os_distro' field is None or empty string - 404 Not Found

Patially-Implements: blueprint api-parameter-validation

Change-Id: I54a75c005cd7dbf406e6dd31a2f27e8e46c0612c

commit_message:
kombu: remove compat of folsom reply format

This change removes codepath where _reply_q is not
present in the message dict.

This kind of messages have been deprecated in grizzly and cannot
be emitted since havana.

https://github.com/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/70891c271e011f59792933eaf65c3214493ef14a

Change-Id: I20558d9fae8f56970c967aa0def77cfb2a1ca3ec

commit_message:
Follow the plan about the single reply message

This change removes the "send_single_reply" option as planned in the bp:

http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/oslo-specs/specs/liberty/oslo.messaging-remove-double-reply.html

Change-Id: Ib88de71cb2008a49a25f302d5e47ed587154d402

commit_message:
[packetary] Introduce command-line interface

Available commands:
- clone - Clones specified repository(es) to local folder.
  packetary clone -o "http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu trusty main restricted universe multiverse" -t deb -d /var/www/mirror/ubuntu

- packages - Gets the list of packages from repository(es).
  packetary packages -o http://mirror.fuel-infra.org/mos-repos/centos/mos8.0-centos6-fuel/os -t yum

- unresolved - Get the list of external dependencies for repository.
  packetary unresolved -o "http://mirror.fuel-infra.org/mos-repos/ubuntu/8.0 mos8.0 main"

Change-Id: I4b3f3fb7b7f2967cf596ed3c7758cfbbf76dfe73
Partial-Bug: #1487077

commit_message:
Fix min value in ttl range of Designate::Record

Current ttl range constraint is incorrect: designate
record requires 1 as minimal value for ttl. So, need to
fix this place.

Change-Id: Ib0423bc2b0412f4e10a3da2f73057c82a9ae14b7
Closes-bug: #1524313

commit_message:
Allow ramdisk_id, kernel_id to be null on schema

Since is possible to create images with no
ramdisk_id, kernel_id parameters on glance v1,
then the schema-image.json needs to be modified to
allow null, string values for both attributes
and prevent LP #1447193 to happen with a glance v2
client.

Change-Id: I1319a1f6bdb69db90f9be7cf34df62cbd8538969
Closes-Bug: #1516330
Related-Bug: #1447193
(cherry picked from commit e39d2209a514c970127141a23864f86c630bddc3)

commit_message:
Add release note covering keystoneauth and v3

The previous two patches added the keystoneauth library and support for
interacting with the rest of the cloud using keystone v3. We should tell
someone about that in our release notes.

Change-Id: I59fcc217c5b8128840add1234aabc2687f3fa6a6

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-11-09 13:59:58.000000000', 'files': ['tripleoclient/tests/test_utils.py', 'tripleoclient/utils.py', 'tripleoclient/v1/undercloud.py', 'tripleoclient/exceptions.py'], 'message': "[liberty backport] Disable command run under root user

Running openstack command with python-tripleoclient under
root user is not supported and should not be allowed. Added
check for user and exit if it is root (EUID=0) to openstack
undercloud install command.

Each command can be disabled for root by adding
utils.ensure_run_as_normal_user() into it's body.

Change-Id: I685c639e02790483d1607c7eac038f8b9b8dc99e
Closes-Bug: rhbz#1239088
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
[liberty backport] Disable command run under root user

Running openstack command with python-tripleoclient under
root user is not supported and should not be allowed. Added
check for user and exit if it is root (EUID=0) to openstack
undercloud install command.

Each command can be disabled for root by adding
utils.ensure_run_as_normal_user() into it's body.

Change-Id: I685c639e02790483d1607c7eac038f8b9b8dc99e
Closes-Bug: rhbz#1239088

subject: Add option to retry decorator to not dump trace
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-09-11 22:03:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Add option to retry decorator to not dump trace

DBDeadlock errors are now common-place in Neutron when
using pymysql, multiple workers, and Galera clusters.
Dumping an exception traceback every time a DBDeadlock
is encountered is not helpful to operators since it's
not really an error condition.

commit_message:
Add option to retry decorator to not dump trace

DBDeadlock errors are now common-place in Neutron when
using pymysql, multiple workers, and Galera clusters.
Dumping an exception traceback every time a DBDeadlock
is encountered is not helpful to operators since it's
not really an error condition.

This adds an option to just log an exception at the debug
level with no trace in the retry decorator.

Change-Id: I38574c8b0d14f868ffa2f1047f6bbd356b55b2fb

commit_message:
Disable ceilometer alarms

Ceilometer alarms is moved different project Aodh.
(Id169a914c1d1f2f5ad03ebb515d3d052204d5c5c). It is still not yet
fully functional from the ceilometer client. This commit disables
the same to avoid errors (HTTPNotFound) during polling.

Change-Id: Ifb6ef1dc51f82972486388b2596ff6112079f817
Partial-Bug:#1522206

commit_message:
Separate Polling Methods in DataSourceDriver to PollingDataSourceDriver

For implementing push type datasource driver, methods related to
polling feature in DataSourceDriver should be separated to
PollingDataSourceDriver. This patch adds PollingDataSourceDriver
which is subclass of DataSourceDriver and has polling features for
some datasource services.

Partially implements blueprint: push-type-datasource-driver

Change-Id: I92cc2f53fa2206fa0f41021eb1278c51b502b509

commit_message:
Fix db error when running python34 Unit tests

If tests for py27 is executed before py34 tests, then
there is a chance that py34 related tests may fail.
The following patch fixes it.

Ref: https://review.openstack.org/#/q/status:merged++topic:bug/1489059,n,z

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I397fe9c6847f3e6d4640adbb2712f2197e72ae47
Closes-bug: #1489059

', 'number': 63}, {'created': '2015-12-01 15:46:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Convert AIO bootstrap from bash to Ansible

This patch converts the AIO bootstrap process to use Ansible
instead of bash scripting. The patch also minimises the options
available to focus the role concerned to just handle an AIO
bootstrap, but gives it just enough flexibility to allow the
use of an external MongoDB database for Ceilometer/Aodh and
for a deployer to specify a secondary disk for the AIO to
consume.

A major change is that the AIO bootstrap process no longer
assumes that it can destroy a secondary boot device. It
requires a device name to be provided. This prevents horrible
surprises.

Implements: blueprint convert-aio-bootstrap-to-ansible
Co-Authored-By: Jesse Pretorius <jesse.pretorius@rackspace.co.uk>

', 'number': 73}, {'created': '2015-12-03 17:28:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Convert AIO bootstrap from bash to Ansible

This patch converts the AIO bootstrap process to use Ansible
instead of bash scripting. The patch also minimises the options
available to focus the role concerned to just handle an AIO
bootstrap, but gives it just enough flexibility to allow the
use of an external MongoDB database for Ceilometer/Aodh and
for a deployer to specify a secondary disk for the AIO to
consume.

Major changes:
- We no longer assume that a secondary device may be automatically
  taken over for the AIO. The bootstrap assumes that it will be
  installed in / unless it is give a secondary device explicitly.
  This prevents horrible surprises. :)
- As run-playbooks is designed for use primarily with the AIO, the
  default behaviour is now set to add the checksum rule to the
  Neutron agent container.
- As it is often surprising to people using the AIO that there are
  no projects, users, networks, etc setup - the default behaviour
  is now to execute the os-tempest-install playbook. This adds a
  demo project, etc which can be used for test work.

TODO (in subsequent patches):
 - update the developer AIO docs
 - convert run-playbooks.sh into an Ansible playbook

commit_message:
Convert AIO bootstrap from bash to Ansible

This patch converts the AIO bootstrap process to use Ansible
instead of bash scripting. The patch also minimises the options
available to focus the role concerned to just handle an AIO
bootstrap, but gives it just enough flexibility to allow the
use of an external MongoDB database for Ceilometer/Aodh and
for a deployer to specify a secondary disk for the AIO to
consume.

A major change is that the AIO bootstrap process no longer
assumes that it can destroy a secondary boot device. It
requires a device name to be provided. This prevents horrible
surprises.

TODO (in subsequent patches):
 - update the developer AIO docs
 - convert run-playbooks.sh into an Ansible playbook

Implements: blueprint convert-aio-bootstrap-to-ansible
Co-Authored-By: Jesse Pretorius <jesse.pretorius@rackspace.co.uk>
Change-Id: I6028952e7260388873f57db47cc3e08126ecc530

subject: Do not wait for MessageHandlingServer
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-12-09 09:32:04.000000000', 'files': ['murano/common/engine.py', 'murano/cmd/engine.py'], 'message': "Do not wait for MessageHandlingServer

Previously oslo.messaging's MessageHandlingServer
was used as as a murano-engine service in service launcher.
As a result it's wait() method was called. But after recent
changes it's wait method is supposed to be call only
after stop() to wait for graceful message processing to end.
As a result a warning was printed that stop() didn't finish
after 30 sec from wait() invocation (because it was never called).

This commit adds EngineService service implementation
that has its own wait() and encapsulates MessageHandlingServer
instance.

Change-Id: Ie553e0b27cc1c261b963907b4f12f89795b99a12
Closes-Bug: #1521087
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Do not wait for MessageHandlingServer

Previously oslo.messaging's MessageHandlingServer
was used as as a murano-engine service in service launcher.
As a result it's wait() method was called. But after recent
changes it's wait method is supposed to be call only
after stop() to wait for graceful message processing to end.
As a result a warning was printed that stop() didn't finish
after 30 sec from wait() invocation (because it was never called).

This commit adds EngineService service implementation
that has its own wait() and encapsulates MessageHandlingServer
instance.

Change-Id: Ie553e0b27cc1c261b963907b4f12f89795b99a12
Closes-Bug: #1521087

[{'created': '2015-11-06 22:12:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "cells: check for existing BDM based on uuid in bdm_update_or_create_at_top

Building off the dependent changes, try to avoid calling
db.block_device_mapping_update_or_create when create=None by checking
to see if a BDM exists with the given uuid first (if set).

If the BDM passed in has a uuid and is in the DB, perform an update, else
create. If the BDM doesn't have a uuid set on it, fall back to the existing
logic used in db.block_device_mapping_update_or_create.

Closes-Bug: #1489581

", 'number': 5}, {'created': '2015-11-09 16:55:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'cells: create block device mappings in API cell

58633c4f085fc21be1e6439bb3d60d7492358d4a stopped the API cell from creating
BDMs since we could end up with duplicate BDMs for the same instance in the
database. This was due to having to key BDMs off the device_name and
volume_id.

Now that the block_device_mapping table and object have a UUID field we can
key off that and let the API cell create the BDM, which should then be used
in the child compute cell.

Any updates to the BDM in the child compute cell, like the compute manager
updating the device_name, will be propagated up to the parent API cell as an
update explicitly. This is so we can stop using the update-or-create construct
which is inherently racy and confusing to trace.

Deprecates BlockDeviceMapping.update_or_create since we are no longer using it
in the compute API and we should drop that in version 2.0 of the BDM object.

Change-Id: I9d2e6055b6cf46865adc57447fabdabeb8cc101b
Closes-Bug: #1489581

', 'number': 7}, {'created': '2015-11-09 20:38:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'cells: create block device mappings in API cell

58633c4f085fc21be1e6439bb3d60d7492358d4a stopped the API cell from creating
BDMs since we could end up with duplicate BDMs for the same instance in the
database. This was due to having to key BDMs off the device_name and
volume_id (which were not yet set in API cell).

Now that the block_device_mapping table and object have a UUID field we can
key off that and let the API cell create the BDM, which should then be used
in the child compute cell.

Any updates to the BDM in the child compute cell, like the compute manager
updating the device_name, will be propagated up to the parent API cell as an
update explicitly. This is so we can stop using the update-or-create construct
which is inherently racy and confusing to trace.

Note that when attaching volumes, the compute manager creates the BDM in the
child cell (see reserve_block_device_name in the compute manager). That is
then sent up to the parent cell via bdm_update_or_create_at_top with
create=True.

Deprecates BlockDeviceMapping.update_or_create since we are no longer using it
in the compute API and we should drop that in version 2.0 of the BDM object.

Change-Id: I9d2e6055b6cf46865adc57447fabdabeb8cc101b
Closes-Bug: #1489581

commit_message:
WIP: cells: create block device mappings in API cell

58633c4f085fc21be1e6439bb3d60d7492358d4a stopped the API cell from creating
BDMs since we could end up with duplicate BDMs for the same instance in the
database. This was due to having to key BDMs off the device_name and
volume_id (which were not yet set in API cell).

Now that the block_device_mapping table and object have a UUID field we can
key off that and let the API cell create the BDM, which should then be used
in the child compute cell.

Any updates to the BDM in the child compute cell, like the compute manager
updating the device_name, will be propagated up to the parent API cell as an
update explicitly. This is so we can stop using the update-or-create construct
which is inherently racy and confusing to trace.

Note that when attaching volumes, the compute manager creates the BDM in the
child cell (see reserve_block_device_name in the compute manager). That is
then sent up to the parent cell via bdm_update_or_create_at_top with
create=True.

Deprecates BlockDeviceMapping.update_or_create since we are no longer using it
in the compute API and we should drop that in version 2.0 of the BDM object.

Change-Id: I9d2e6055b6cf46865adc57447fabdabeb8cc101b
Closes-Bug: #1489581

commit_message:
Revert "Exclude all BDM checks for cells"

This reverts commit fa203c3165d4ac61e1c191e6d3c6db54778c3ed7

We should have this fixed now that we're using the BDM uuid
when checking to see if we should update or create a BDM in the
parent cell.

Change-Id: I0ead742c011a954f7aa079495bb3b31b7c27e1f4
Related-Bug: #1489581

commit_message:
Remove py26 support

As of mitaka, the infra team won't have the resources available to
reasonably test py26, also the oslo team is dropping py26 support
from their libraries. sine we rely on oslo for a lot of our work,
and depend on infra for our CI, we should drop py26 support too.
Closes-Bug: 1519510
Depends-On: Ic8241e55b5f4e3d567156d4c1e8bf8a0303f6d29

Change-Id: I4386dc70e3d467e31963d852726af78fbdbbba38

commit_message:
Use node.uuid directly in stop_console()

There's no need to call _parse_driver_info() to convert all
parameters, we can directly use node.uuid.

Change-Id: I88fb5901de91236c67cafb36030fe9bf46824067

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-10-03 14:29:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "[WIP] Use diffs for iptables restore instead of all rules

Rather than dumping thousands of rules into iptables-restore
every single time we call it, wouldn't it be nice if we could
just send the delta between the previous version and the new
version? If you think so, continue reviewing this patch!!!

This patch changes our iptables logic to generate a delta of
iptables commands (inserts + deletes) to get from the current
iptables state to the new state. This will significantly reduce
the amount of data that we have to shell out to iptables-restore
on every call (and reduce the amount of data iptables-restore has
to parse).

Change-Id: Ia6470c85b6b71979006ffe5da9095fdcce3122c1
", 'number': 1}, {'created': '2015-10-04 14:48:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "[WIP] Use diffs for iptables restore instead of all rules

Rather than dumping thousands of rules into iptables-restore
every single time we call it, wouldn't it be nice if we could
just send the delta between the previous version and the new
version? If you think so, continue reviewing this patch!!!

This patch changes our iptables logic to generate a delta of
iptables commands (inserts + deletes) to get from the current
iptables state to the new state. This will significantly reduce
the amount of data that we have to shell out to iptables-restore
on every call (and reduce the amount of data iptables-restore has
to parse).

Also, we no longer have to worry about preserving counters since
we are adding and deleting specific rules, so the rule modification
code got a nice cleanup to get rid of the old rule matching.

TODO: functional testing - we now have a cool property where the
      _apply_rules function should not modify anything on the second
      run. this can be leveraged to assert that all of our rule
      matching is correct.
      performance measurements - this should result in significant
      speedups in the _modify_rules function and the call to
      iptables-save

Change-Id: Ia6470c85b6b71979006ffe5da9095fdcce3122c1

", 'number': 5}, {'created': '2015-10-05 10:24:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "[WIP] Use diffs for iptables restore instead of all rules

Rather than dumping thousands of rules into iptables-restore
every single time we call it, wouldn't it be nice if we could
just send the delta between the previous version and the new
version? If you think so, continue reviewing this patch!!!

This patch changes our iptables logic to generate a delta of
iptables commands (inserts + deletes) to get from the current
iptables state to the new state. This will significantly reduce
the amount of data that we have to shell out to iptables-restore
on every call (and reduce the amount of data iptables-restore has
to parse).

Also, we no longer have to worry about preserving counters since
we are adding and deleting specific rules, so the rule modification
code got a nice cleanup to get rid of the old rule matching.

TODO: functional testing - we now have a cool property where the
      _apply_rules function should not modify anything on the second
      run. this can be leveraged to assert that all of our rule
      matching is correct.
      performance measurements - this should result in significant
      speedups in the _modify_rules function and the call to
      iptables-save

Change-Id: Ia6470c85b6b71979006ffe5da9095fdcce3122c1
", 'number': 6}, {'created': '2015-10-05 13:22:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Use diffs for iptables restore instead of all rules

Rather than dumping thousands of rules into iptables-restore
every single time we call it, wouldn't it be nice if we could
just send the delta between the previous version and the new
version? If you think so, continue reviewing this patch!!!

This patch changes our iptables logic to generate a delta of
iptables commands (inserts + deletes) to get from the current
iptables state to the new state. This will significantly reduce
the amount of data that we have to shell out to iptables-restore
on every call (and reduce the amount of data iptables-restore has
to parse).

This patch also adds an option that I suggest we enable in the
gate that will will run the apply function twice whenever it
makes a change in order to verify that the second one didn't
try to make any changes as well. This will help us catch iptables
rules that we aren't constructing in the same manner as the
iptables-save output.

Also, we no longer have to worry about preserving counters since
we are adding and deleting specific rules, so the rule modification
code got a nice cleanup to get rid of the old rule matching.

TODO: test adjustments/new tests

Performance metrics relative to HEAD~1:
====================================+============+=======+
               Scenario             | This patch | HEAD~1|
------------------------------------|------------|-------|
 200 VMs*22 rules existing - startup|            |       |
                       _modify_rules|   0.67s    | 1.05s |
                 _apply_synchronized|   1.87s    | 2.89s |
------------------------------------|------------|-------|
 200 VMs*22 rules existing - add VM |            |       |
                       _modify_rules|   0.68s    | 1.05s |
                 _apply_synchronized|   2.07s    | 2.92s |
------------------------------------+------------+-------+
200 VMs*422 rules existing - startup|            |       |
                       _modify_rules|   5.43s    | 8.17s |
                 _apply_synchronized|  12.77s    |28.00s |
------------------------------------|------------|-------|
200 VMs*422 rules existing - add VM |            |       |
                       _modify_rules|   6.41s    | 8.33s |
                 _apply_synchronized|  33.09s    |33.80s |
------------------------------------+------------+-------+

The _apply_synchronized times seem to converge when dealing
with ~85k rules. In the profile I can see that both approaches
seem to wait on iptables-restore for approximately the same
amount of time so it could be hitting the performance limits
of iptables-restore.

commit_message:
Use diffs for iptables restore instead of all rules

This patch changes our iptables logic to generate a delta of
iptables commands (inserts + deletes) to get from the current
iptables state to the new state. This will significantly reduce
the amount of data that we have to shell out to iptables-restore
on every call (and reduce the amount of data iptables-restore has
to parse).

We no longer have to worry about preserving counters since
we are adding and deleting specific rules, so the rule modification
code got a nice cleanup to get rid of the old rule matching.

This also gives us a new method of functionally testing that we are
generating rules in the correct manner. After applying new rules
once, a subsequent call should always have no work to do. The new
functional tests added leverage that property heavily and should
protect us from regressions in how rules are formed.


Performance metrics relative to HEAD~1:
+====================================+============+=======+
|               Scenario             | This patch | HEAD~1|
|------------------------------------|------------|-------|
| 200 VMs*22 rules existing - startup|            |       |
|                       _modify_rules|   0.67s    | 1.05s |
|                 _apply_synchronized|   1.87s    | 2.89s |
|------------------------------------|------------|-------|
| 200 VMs*22 rules existing - add VM |            |       |
|                       _modify_rules|   0.68s    | 1.05s |
|                 _apply_synchronized|   2.07s    | 2.92s |
|------------------------------------+------------+-------+
|200 VMs*422 rules existing - startup|            |       |
|                       _modify_rules|   5.43s    | 8.17s |
|                 _apply_synchronized|  12.77s    |28.00s |
|------------------------------------|------------|-------|
|200 VMs*422 rules existing - add VM |            |       |
|                       _modify_rules|   6.41s    | 8.33s |
|                 _apply_synchronized|  33.09s    |33.80s |
+------------------------------------+------------+-------+

The _apply_synchronized times seem to converge when dealing
with ~85k rules. In the profile I can see that both approaches
seem to wait on iptables-restore for approximately the same
amount of time so it could be hitting the performance limits
of iptables-restore.
